conclusion: The problem involves finding the horizontal distance between a person on a cruise ship and a submarine underwater using principles of optics and trigonometry.
Given values: height of the person to the water surface (h1) = 15 m, underwater depth of the submarine (h2) = 23 m, refractive index of water (n) = 4/3, sin(53°) = 0.8, cos(53°) = 0.6.
The apparent height of the submarine above the water surface is h3 = h2 × n = 23 × 4/3 = 34.67 m.
The hypotenuse (distance from the submarine to the person) is d = √(h1² + h3²) = √(15² + 34.67²).
The calculated hypotenuse is d = √(225 + 1201.11) = √1444.09 ≈ 37.6 m.
The horizontal distance from the submarine to the person is d - h3 = 37.6 - 34.67 = 2.93 m.
Convert the horizontal distance to centimeters: 2.93 m = 2.93 × 10³ cm = 2930 cm.
Convert the horizontal distance back to meters: 2930 cm × (1/1000) = 2.93 m.
The horizontal distance between the submarine and the person is approximately 2.93 meters.
